Label: Abraham of Kütahya style
Scopenote: Style of Iznik pottery named after Abraham of Kutahya whose name is on a ewer in the BM reg no. G.1983.1. Objects were made in this style between circa 1490-1520.

Label: Afro-Portuguese Style
Scopenote: A style of ivory carving, combining European and African features.

Label: American
Scopenote: USA only.

Label: Animal Chalice style
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

Label: Austrian
Scopenote: For artists working at any time in the area of the modern state of Austria. See also under GERMAN.

Label: Bahu Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Bahu in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

Label: Basohli Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings associated with the court of Basohli, an offshoot of the Kulu royal house. The artists at Basohli developed a striking early painting style where the compositions were painted in bright colours and accentuated with luminous beetle wings cut out and pasted to the painted surface. These works are characterised by bold colour schemes, monochromatic backgrounds and exaggerated facial features through, for example, the shape of the eye. This vigorous bright style was retained until the early 18th century; later works include a more naturalistic landscape, and a softer colour palette.

Label: Belgian
Scopenote: For artists working after 1800.

Label: Bencharong Style
Scopenote: Term used for ceramics produced in Southern China for the Thai market, in the 18th and 19th centuries.

Label: Bengal School
Scopenote: The term refers to the work of late 19thC and 20thC Calcutta artists.

Label: Bikaner Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings from the court of Bikaner, the earliest of which date to the late sixteenth century. Bikaner rulers may have invited Mughal artists into their courtly retinue as early as the 17th century and instead of the traditional bold colour patterns and flat compositions, Bikaner artists started to experiment with a softer colour palette dominated by earth tones. Their figures were rendered more naturalistically through the use of shading and perspective. As a vassal of the Mughal empire, Bikaner rulers were also charged with running campaigns into the Deccan. Early Deccani influence in the luscious colouring and compositional format are also apparent.

Label: Bilaspur Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Bilaspur in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

Label: Black-figure Grand style
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery style after Lemos 1991.

Label: Bohemian
Scopenote: For artists working up to 1919.

Label: Bukhara School
Scopenote: This school flourished under the Shaybanid Dynasty.

Label: Bundi Style
Scopenote: This term refers to painting from the court of Bundi from the late sixteenth century to the early nineteenth century. Bundi was one of the earliest courts to accept Mughal rule when in 1569 the fort of Ranthambhor fell to the Mughal force. The earliest paintings from Bundi date to this period – namely the Chunar Ragamala, now dispersed.

Label: Chalice style
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

Label: Chamba Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Chamba in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

Label: Company School
Scopenote: This term refers to a wide range of drawings and paintings created by South Asian artists that were commissioned by European patrons, or intended for a European market. The subject matter is frequently descriptive of the ‘Indian Scene’ and prepared in sets or albums. Works can be attributed to a variety of sub-styles dependent on the artists’ regional training. The works often incorporate stylistic traits from both the South Asian and European traditions prevalent and popular in the region in the 18th and 19th centuries.

Label: Czech
Scopenote: For artists working after 1992; otherwise use CZECHOSLOVAKIAN.

Label: Czechoslovakian
Scopenote: For artists working between 1919 and 1992.

Label: Deccani School
Scopenote: The term refers to paintings from Golconda, Bijapur, Ahmadnagar, Berar and Bidar, from the 16thC to the 18thC. The term 'Deccani School' should be entered in addition to any Narrower Terms where available.

Label: Devgarh Style
Scopenote: This term refers to painting at the Mewari sub court between c. 1766–1850. The Devgarh style is an offshoot of the Udaipur court style and consists predominantly of portraits of the rulers (Rawats), genre scenes, and illustrations of the life of Krishna.

Label: Dutch
Scopenote: For artists working after 1579.

Label: Early Celtic Art
Scopenote: This applies to For Iron age objects which are decorated with La Tene motifs.

Label: Early Rajput Style
Scopenote: This term was coined by Robert Skelton (in his unpublished lecture at SOAS, London, in 1974) and is now fairly widely accepted as a valid descriptive term for painting emerging from Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Malwa, Gujarat and the Rajasthani courts in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

Label: Enman class
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

Label: Flemish
Scopenote: For artists working between 1579 and 1830.

Label: Garhwal Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Garhwal in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

Label: German
Scopenote: See also under AUSTRIAN.

Label: Grand style
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

Label: Guler Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings from the court of Guler in the Punjab Hills. Paintings in this style tend to include elegant and undulating lines, prominent outlines, naturalistic landscape, and a soft colour palette.

Label: Inju School
Scopenote: School of painting in Shiraz from 1330s to 1350s.

Label: Irish
Scopenote: For artists working after 1921.

Label: Isfahan Style
Scopenote: The term refers to either paintings from provincial centres in the style of the Isfahan School, or to copies or fakes of the Isfahan School.

Label: Islamic Painting School
Scopenote: The term covers Arab, Turkish, Persian and Islamic Indian painting from 1200 to circa 1925.

Label: Jaipur Style
Scopenote: This term refers to painting from the court of Jaipur in the eighteenth and early nineteenth century. The Kachhwaha clan of Jaipur were initially established at the nearby court of Amber, while Jaipur, a purpose-built city, was founded in 1728 by Raja Sawai Jai Singh II. The term can also be applied to earlier paintings from Amber, however the date should indicate if the work was painted before or after the move to Jaipur.

Label: Jammu Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Jammu in the Punjab Hills. The early works associated with Jammu are characterised by bold colour schemes, monochromatic backgrounds and exaggerated facial features. This vigorous bright style was retained until the early 18th century; later works include a more naturalistic landscape, and a softer colour palette.

Label: Japanese style
Scopenote: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects, mainly in P&E. See Japanese and its Narrow Terms for two-dimensional objects.

Label: Jodhpur Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings from the court of Jodhpur, capital of Marwar in the central desert region of Rajasthan. The earliest known painted works from Marwar is a Ragamala Series dated 1623. Stylistic traits often associated with Jodhpur include the sharply flaring skirt of the jama and thick mutton chop side-whiskers.

Label: Kakiemon Style
Scopenote: The term refers to porcelain of European manufacture, decorated to imitate Japanese Kakiemon porcelain (which was produced from the mid-17thC onwards). See also Kakiemon Ware in Ware.

Label: Kalighat Style
Scopenote: The term refers to a style of painting associated with the famous Kali temple in Calcutta known as the Kalighat temple. Sacred souvenirs in the form of paintings were produced here from the 1850s until the early decades of the 20th century.

Label: Kangra Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings from Kangra. Little exists before the mid-18th century, however this relatively late flowering, created some astounding examples. The large state of Kangra extended from Nurpur and Chamba along its northern borders to Mandi in the east and the Punjab plains towards the south-west.

Label: Khmer Style
Scopenote: The term refers to an artistic style associated with the medieval inhabitants of Cambodia; also represented in adjacent parts of Thailand. The Material Culture or Period term 'Khmer' should also be entered.

Label: Khurasan Style
Scopenote: The term refers to a painting style produced in the late 16thC produced in North-eastern Iran.

Label: Khurasan Type
Scopenote: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects.

Label: Kishangarh Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings from the court of Kishangarh from the seventeenth to the late eighteenth century. The rulers of Kishangarh were devotees of Lord Vishnu and his worship was a defining influence on the arts – images of the love dalliance between Krishna and Radha were often produced. Patronage of painting probably began under Man Singh (r. 1658-1706) in the Mughal style of Aurangzeb and elongated figures, with a slight arching of back, and oversized eyes became the norm.

Label: Knipovitch group
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

Label: Komast group
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

Label: Kota Style
Scopenote: This term refers to painting from the small court of Kota from the seventeenth century to the nineteenth century. The Mughals established Kota as an independent state from Bundi to be ruled by a branch of the family in 1631 and stylistically, the early art of Kota followed the Bundi model and concentrated on Ragamala and Baramasa painting. As it flourished in the eighteenth century there was a marked increase in the production of hunting scenes – tigers prowling dense jungles of tightly composed foliage, with hunters interspersed between the trees. The figures have a ruddier complexion in comparison to Bundi painting, with sculpturally modelled features.

Label: Malmalkot Style
Scopenote: A style of sundress from Malmalkot in Vanuatu

Label: Malwa Style
Scopenote: This term refers to works from central India dating to the late 16th and early 17th century.

Label: Mandalay Style
Scopenote: Term used for a style of sculpture first produced under the kings of Burma who ruled from Mandalay (c.1850-1885). This style is remains popular today especially for Buddha images. These Buddha figures are characterised by a wide headband between the hair and forehead, a rounded usnisha, and an ornately pleated and folded robe. The inclusion of coloured and mirrored glass is also a distinctive feature.

Label: Mandi Style
Scopenote: This term refers to painting from the small court of Mandi in the Punjab Hills.

Label: Mankot Style
Scopenote: Small court of the Pahari Hills. The ruling family of Mankot were closely associated with Jammu (claiming descent from a Jammu raja and belonging to the Jammu Riasi family) yet they remained independent. The painting style associated with the court flourished in the 18th century. Episodes from the life of Krishna, as told through the 10th book of the Bhagavata Purana, were often illustrated.

Label: Marchigian
Scopenote: From the Marches

Label: Maruyama-Shijo School
Scopenote: The term refers to the modern name given to the combined schools of painters Maruyama Okyo and Go Shun, which began in Kyoto in the late 18th century and spread to Osaka and Edo.

Label: Mewar Style
Scopenote: This is a broad term that that encompasses the courtly style of Udaipur, as well as the sub court styles of Devgarh, Nathdwara, etc. This term should be used when the painting is the work of an Udaipur-trained artist, yet the patron is unknown.

Label: Middle East and North Africa Modern Art
Scopenote: The term covers all objects dated from the 20thC onwards, made in the Middle East and North Africa or by artists originating from that region. North Africa includes Algeria, Morocco, Libya and Tunisia.

Label: Minyao
Scopenote: Type of Chinese ceramics.

Label: Mixteca-Puebla Style
Scopenote: Style found in Mexico.

Label: Mosan
Scopenote: This refers to a style of enamelling developed in centres in the Meuse Valley, but later adopted in workshops in the Middle Rhine, Champagne region, Ile de France and even England.

Label: Mount Hagen
Scopenote: Mount Hagen Style from the Mount Hagen region, Papua New Guinea

Label: Mughal Style
Scopenote: The term refers to the Mughal style of painting, 1555-1800.

Label: Nathdvara Style
Scopenote: Painting from the pilgrimage site of Nathdvara revolved around the temple of Srinathji. Artists from as far away as Mewar, Kota, Ajmer and Delhi migrated to the centre in the eighteenth century to create images for travelling pilgrims and visiting nobles.

Label: Neo-Tantric Style
Scopenote: The term refers to the work of a group of Indian painters of the post independence period who drew inspiration from the texts known as Tantras. Much of their work uses abstract and/or sexual imagery.

Label: Netherlandish
Scopenote: For artists working up to 1579.

Label: Nicoya Style
Scopenote: The term refers to a Central American style alluding to provenance from the Nicoya Peninsula.

Label: Nihonga School
Scopenote: The term refers to a Japanese school of painting with traditional themes, style and technique since the late nineteenth century.

Label: Oriental style
Scopenote: The term and its Narrow Terms are restricted to three-dimensional objects.

Label: Ottoman School
Scopenote: The term refers to paintings produced in the Ottoman Empire from the 16thC to the late 19thC.

Label: Pahari School
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings created in the small Rajput courts of the Punjab Hills. While the Pahari region was occupied from the 7th century onwards, with dated architectural monuments and temples, there is no evidence of painting until the mid-16th century. The painting tradition really flourished from the 17th to the 19th centuries.

Label: Paithan Style
Scopenote: Paintings used in story-telling by itinerant bards. Typical of the Andhra Pradesh/Karnataka border area and not - as was once thought - with the town of Paithan, further to the northwest. Although incorrect, this terminology is still in use (the mistaken provenance originally came about because early collections of these paintings were acquired in the town of Paithan). They are often double-sided, though in museum collections they have frequently been divided. Subjects include the epics, frequently with local characters and scenes interpolated. They are painted in a highly stylised manner and are clearly linked to the shadow-puppet tradition of Karnataka.

Label: Petrie group
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

Label: Plain Body group
Scopenote: The term refers to a transitional style in Archaic South Ionian pottery between Wild Goat and Fikellura.

Label: Popoyan Style
Scopenote: The term refers to a gold-working style in Columbia.

Label: Poultry group
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

Label: Provincial Mughal Style
Scopenote: The term refers to paintings that reflect the Mughal Painting Style but were presumably produced at provincial centres.

Label: Qajar School
Scopenote: The term refers to works produced in Qajar Iran of the late 18thC and 19thC..

Label: Qazvin Style
Scopenote: The term refers to the court style of painting in Iran c.1550-1598.

Label: Rajasthan School
Scopenote: The term 'Rajasthan School' should be entered in addition to any Narrower Terms where available.

Label: Romagna
Scopenote: District of Emilia-Romagna, south of Bologna: Faenza, Rimini, Forlì.

Label: Rumi
Scopenote: Style of design on Iznik pottery, referring to traditional arabesque (Islamic) patterns.

Label: Safavid Type
Scopenote: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects.

Label: Sasanian Type
Scopenote: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects.

Label: Shin hanga
Scopenote: The term refers to a revival of traditional collaborative printmaking from the 1910s to the postwar period.

Label: Slovak
Scopenote: For artists working after 1992; see also CZECHOSLOVAKIAN.

Label: Sosaku hanga
Scopenote: The term refers to a school of modern Japanese printmaking from about 1910, in which artists generally cut and print their own blocks in relatively small editions.

Label: South Asian
Scopenote: For the Company, Pahari, Rajasthan Schools, these terms are entered as well as the Narrower terms for Styles.

Label: Sphinx and Lion style
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

Label: Style I
Scopenote: Berhnard Salin's first early Germanic animal style.

Label: Style II
Scopenote: Berhnard Salin's second early Germanic animal style.

Label: Style III
Scopenote: Berhnard Salin's third early Germanic animal style.

Label: Sultanate Style
Scopenote: The term refers to a style of painting from various centres in pre-Mughal India.

Label: Tongoa style
Scopenote: Style of island dress, originating in Tongoa island, Vanuatu.

Label: Tübingen group
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

Label: Udaipur Style
Scopenote: This term refers to painting at the main court of Udaipur in Mewar, Rajasthan. When this term is used, the presumed patron is the Maharana. The earliest documented Mewar royal patronage of painting occurred in 1605 and the painting atelier continued to be active until the 20th century.

Label: Ujjain Style
Scopenote: This term refers to paintings from the sub-court of Ujjain , a fiefdom of Bundi. The painting style is linked to the main court of Bundi and the artists commissioned by the Ujjain patrons may have in fact trained in Bundi.

Label: Urla group
Scopenote: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

Label: Western India Style
Scopenote: This term refers to Jain painting dating to the mid to late sixteenth century. Jain merchants controlled the trade in this area of north India and were the predominant patrons of manuscripts between the twelfth and late fifteenth centuries. The majority of commissions were of illustrated religious texts, particularly the Kalpasutra. A conspicuous trait of Jain painting is the use of the further projecting eye; other defining traits include a thin and wiry line used to delineate figures shown most often in full profile, a complete lack of modelling, and architectural features used primarily as background motifs.

Label: Yugoslav
Scopenote: For artists working between 1919 and 1992.

Label: Zhe School
Scopenote: The term refers to a Ming dynasty School of painting.
